question: Question_02_(a)
statement:
Define what it means for a function $f$ to be continuous at a point
\emph{a}.
sols:
A function $f$ is continuous as a point \emph{a} if:

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $f(a)$ is defined
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\displaystyle \lim_{x \to a} f(x)$ exists, i.e.
  $\displaystyle \lim_{x \to a^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to a^+} f(x) = L$
  where \emph{L} is finite.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\displaystyle \lim_{x \to a} = f(a)$
\end{enumerate}

The first and third conditions ensure that the drawing of $f$ has no
holes; the second and third conditions ensure that the drawing of $f$ has
no jumps.
hints:
A function is continuous if its graph has no holes or jumps. How can a
hole or jump be described using mathematical language?
